review_title: Mandate incongruent to the reality of everyday work
job_title: Senior Project Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great and important mandate which focuses on improving the lives of women, girls (and all youth) in the most vulnerable of settings through interventions in GBV and SRH.
cons: Retention, rotation, promotion of senior leadership needs a complete overhaul. Place over-run by senior level incompetents and bullies who either get shifted from country office to regional office, to HQ and back again after something has gone very very wrong (e.g. harassment, mis-management, insubordination), making the place unsafe and toxic. Political appointments are way too many, esp. of persons who are ill-fit for the job and can bring entire divisions down and put the place at severe risk. Basic background checks needs improvement- hiring persons under investigation, who have been fired in previous jobs, who been reported against in previous roles can easily be found out if checks are done well- but having reference checks that can be filled out by your cousins won't capture that!

review_title: Wonderful mandate but poor management culture
pros:
- Its mandate will get in your heart
- Presence in more than 150 countries
- Provides standard UN salary and benefits, a privileged package
cons:
- Extremely vertical hierarchy, you must be very aware of who you can and cannot address directly 
- Complete lack of transparency in management decisions, which also means that meritocracy is hardly a thing in the organization: staff members are more likely to advance for pleasing the right person than for doing good work
- Poor investment in the professional development of employees (e.g.: if you want to become a better professional by taking courses, be ready to pay for those courses with your own money and use your personal leave for the time you need to attend the classes)

review_title: Corrupt, moribund bureaucracy with a ton of cash. Great place for lazy, sleazy middle-aged sheisters.
job_title: Resigned Fixed-term HQ in New York, NY
pros: Everyone is massively overpaid, no one is ever fired no matter what you do, six weeks paid vacation, great medical and dental, endless lunch hours, and no accountability for actually performing work, because it's "process over product" or whatever the current excuse is.
cons:
If you care what you are spending your life doing, you may have problems working at UNFPA. But if the "plusses" noted above are enough to satisfy your selfish interests, go for it. No one is watching. 

Your enthusiasm may eventually get ground down when it sinks in that there is no hope of promotion without office-political connections, no one cares whether you do great work or sit at your desk drinking wine, and you have become a living, lunching, gucci-blinging mockery of everything the UN was founded on.

review_title: Don't join this agency for humanitarian aid work
pros: Nice mandate, some nice work for women's reproductive health rights, some passionate personnel
cons:
The organization doesn't know where it is heading in humanitarian aid, and quite frankly, I'm not sure if UNFPA has a reason to exist within that realm. While it claims to be UN's reproductive health agency, in reality it tries to encompass two separate aspects - sexual & reproductive health (SRH) and gender-based violence (GBV).

The  SRH aspect competes with WHO (health cluster general), UNHCR (refugee health), and UNICEF (child health). The GBV aspect competes with UNHCR (protection) and UNICEF (child protection). The competing agencies invest heavily in technical assets and corporate branding strategy, but UNFPA does not do so in neither. As a result, its presence in humanitarian remains very weak, and makes fieldwork that much more difficult - not to mention it fails to attract high-quality funding.

There's also a severe lack of organizational policies for proper R&R and efficient logistics, which bring down team morale when the pressure is tremendous but the topside moves way too slow, even per UN standards.

pros: The work itself is greatly challenging therefore provides growth and development. Career opportunities development with the assistance of the organization. The experience of working with staff members from diverse background. The benefits on being an international staff  leads to self commitment and desire to learn more. The organization ever changing systems widens your understanding that we are in a changing world and therefore requires one to be flexible and innovative.
cons: Its the job security part of it. The 1 year contract is not viable. The Medical Aid is not friendly. It is more stressful sometime.

review_title: Fast and very dynamic working atmosphere with great chance to gain skills and experience to work on very complex project
pros: Gaining knowledge on complex programmes and projects related to Reproductive Health and Youth development. Overall introduction to International Affairs and skills how to communicate with government officials and providing support to project implementing partners. gaining experience in event management through organization of conferences and working group meetings. Building reporting and planning skills. Introduction to financial issues of project implementation. Learning how to lead your project based on UNFPA result based management.
cons: Lots of stress due to shortage of staff needed to implement programmes. Small chances for promotion for SSA contract holders.

pros: Good salary, Benefits:  6 weeks annual leave, paid sick leave, insurance, pension plan, flexible work schedule, above-average office environment, you can meet interesting people from all over the world.  Overall work environment is calmer than before.
cons: Uneven management, Internal and International Politics can influence many things, Recruitment can be slow, favoritism, Morale can be low especially for long time staff and general service, a cumbersome review process which doesn't seem to serve any real purpose.  Funding is not always reliable.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: United Nations organization with one of the most practical, relevant and interesting mandates. The humanitarian intervention, particularly in the areas of fistula prevention and treatment and maternal health are interesting and highly commendable. It feels good to work in an organization that makes a visible difference.
cons: Extremely stressful environment in which to work, although the stress factor may be determined by the unit in which you work and the personality of your immediate supervisor. There also seems to be insufficient gender balance, and the life of a woman seems to be a bit harder.

review_title: Why so many years at UNFPA?
job_title: Technical Specialist, PD in Luanda, Luanda
pros:
It is extremely gratifying to receive notification of 10 years of serving the UNFPA. For me it is also special time for reflections and of curse an obvious questions comes in the mind:

Why so many years at UNFPA?
Ten years of hard work, many times of adapting to the strategic changes in the organization and always proud to be part of the UNFPA family.  When looking back, I see times when UNFPA CO in Mozambique became a Young people organization because of the innovated successful ASRH Programme “Geração BIZ”, being implemented in all 11 provinces of Mozambique and donors feeling proud to give more and more money to UNFPA CO in recognition of the valuable results being achieved for this very vulnerable group that today have being recognized in our SP and BM as one of UNFPA main target group. Furthermore, I see with great satisfaction when during the 2007 census the CO mobilized around 19 million US Dollars and some of donors explained why they are supporting Census via-UNFPA… “We are giving money to UNFPA because demonstrated good management of funds; timely submission of reports, integrity of its staff and other positive things that we heard with other donors who worked with UNFPA before” said a senior manager of one of UN donors in Mozambique. This declaration reminded me and make me always aware that integrity, transparency, accountability are important elements to foster trust in any partnership. This is what I am taking with me over the 10 years and will continue being through the remaining time with this vibrant organization that implement one of fascinating mandate.

 

Cheers
cons: Poor mechanism to identify and recognize staff with exceptional performance in the field. Currently rely manly on the Representatives and PADs.

review_title: New Executive Director Starts to Work on the Changes within the System
pros: It is very flexible environment and also there are many internal on-job opportunities to  extend the knowledge on sexual and reproductive rights.  The mandate of the agency is very important and sometimes can be challenging.
cons: Contractual agreements are not very favorable for the local staff , because most of the time they issue service contract instead of other staff modalities and therefore not all benefits could be used.  In small field offices there are not many opportunities to go up on higher positions.

review_title: The level of CARE in people and people practices needs to improve
pros: Excellent mandate which currently meets the heightened needs of the most vulnerable on the ground.
cons: Our office is one of great contrasts - a few great people overwhelmed with work on poorer contracts, and then persons who for some reasons are holding posts of authority and seemingly underemployed who spend a lot of time going to workshops. If anyone is at workshop 40% of the time, what are they actually doing? I went into HQ twice this year for various meetings.  First time I stopped into DHR to get counsel on several pending recruitment issues we had in our office and was given little clarity, after months of waiting.  DHR don't seem to understand the implications of how their delays affect people's lives, the undue stress this puts persons and their families under. Then I walked through another time and there was a  staff member openly complaining, another visibly upset about something.  It did not leave me with great confidence.
